content.description: Same start as for Don't Cross the Line, move straight up on solid crimps, top out straight up. Best warm-up on the rock
content.location: Same as for Don't Cross the Line

content.description: With a foot out left, pull on to the two small crimps found in the middle of the front face of the boulder. Pull up and hit the jug, same finish hold as Don't Cross the Line and Clam Shell Left, directly above you and top out straight up, same as those two climbs.
content.protection: Couple of pads. High dab potential on this climb, so watch where you put them.
content.location: Start is on the right side of the face, in between both small roofs on the right and left side of the boulder.  There are two small, obvious crimps, in the middle of a seam int he middle of this face.

content.description: Start on the lowest crimp on the left side of the boulder, make several moves up and trending right on solid crimps.  The crux of the route is a hard move with the right hand to a sharp half pad crimp that sets the climber up for a dyno/deadpoint to the lip.
content.location: The route starts on the left most edge of the boulder on the lowest usable crimps

content.description:
This climb starts using the same holds as Jungle Lane and Don't Cross the Line.  Traverse right, making the same moves as for Don't Cross the Line.  

   Instead of exiting the climb straight up in the middle of the face, work further right through two unpleasant crimps to the right face of this rock.  Use some funky foot beta to switch your feet from the left to right side of the rock and then use the right arete to top out. 

  The crux of the climb is arguably not dabbing while working yourself through the two sharp crimps.
content.protection: Pads along the rock. Make sure they are far enough away you do not dab.
content.location: Park at Hazard Ave in Narragansett and hike down to the water. This boulder is about 100 meters south down the cast. So one you get to the water, turn right, walk for maybe 5 minutes, and the small, overhanging boulder will be sitting about 30-40' up from the water line along a small ridge below the houses.

content.description: Same start as for Clam Shell Left, start with left hand in one of the two small crimps on the face and right hand on the rail under the roof on the right side of the boulder. Instead of bumping up on to the face bump out to the right arete.  Move your feet around so you can bring the left up to match the arete and then pull over for an easy topout.
content.protection: Pads. Bring a few, the landing sucks. The topout is easy but a fall there could be bad without proper padding.
content.location: Start on the right arete of the boulder. sitting with your right half under the small roof. Trend right to the arete instead of left onto the face like Clam Shell Left.

content.description: Start with left hand in one of the two small crimps on the face and right hand on the rail under the roof on the right side of the boulder.  Pull on and bump the right hand up to the good jug rail just below the lip and then top out straight up as for Hazard Direct and Don't Cross the Line.
content.protection: Pads. Bring a few, the landing sucks.
content.location: Start on the right arete of the boulder. sitting with your right half under the small roof. Trend left to the face instead of right to the arete like Clam Shell Right.

content.description: Hazrd Rock is a small boulder located about 40' away from the water, there are a few short overhung climbs on this rock. The rock texture is similar to Black Point with mostly coarse weathered granite.  The boulder is fairly secluded but it is right near a house on Ocean rd so make sure to watch the noise levels.
